title: $AFRM Freedom Capital Markets Starts at Buy PT $90
content:
$AFRM Freedom Capital Markets Starts at Buy PT $90
Affirm is considered the category leader in Buy Now Pay Later (â€˜BNPLâ€™) payment options to consumers in the U.S., with international expansion on the horizon. BNPL as a payment option has seen exponential growth over the past decade, with its share of eCommerce increasing from ~2% (2020) to ~6% (2024). Affirm has been a tremendous share gainer in the U.S. which has translated into a GAAP profitable business (L3Qs) and a +mid-20s grower delivering high-20s adj. op. inc. margins which are poised for meaningful expansion. We see several catalysts on the horizon to deliver upside to consensus estimates and initiate with a Buy rating on shares and a $90 PT predicated on 14x our CY26 RLTC of $2.1B (or 39x our CY27E GAAP EPS of $2.32)

title: TLT short interest shows a textbook mismatch betwe...
content:
TLT short interest shows a textbook mismatch between what traders are betting on and what the actual market is doing. 
Short interest in TLT (a 20+ year Treasury bond ETF) has hit an all-time high while the ETF price itself has been declining from recent peaks. 
Basically, a massive number of traders have borrowed TLT shares and sold them short, betting the price will keep falling. 
TLT prices move inverse to interest rates, when rates fall, bonds rally hard. 
Right now, the labor market is weakening faster than expected, and the market is pricing in a significant probability of a Fed rate cut at the December meeting. 
If rates do come down, TLT doesn't just go up a little, it can spike significantly, especially on a 20-year duration bond.
 All those shorts who are underwater would be forced to cover by buying back their shares, which creates a feedback loop that pushes prices even higher. 
The really interesting part is how much of this short position is actually driven by options dealers hedging call options rather than pure directional bets.
$TLT short interest jumps to an all-time high 
ğŸ“ˆ
ğŸ“ˆ
 Here we go! https://t.co/QXqs0VNfUQ 
- 
Barchart

â€œCelestial AI is deeply engaged with multiple hyperscalersâ€¦ [and] has already secured a major design win with one of the worldâ€™s largest hyperscalers who plans to use Celestial AIâ€™s PEF chiplets in its next generation scale up architecture.â€

title: Look at that RUN!
content:
Look at that RUN!
 
https://t.co/V8SqtEsaih

title: Wild, if true.
content:
Wild, if true.
This is WILD.
Tesla just showed Optimus running. Not the stiff, pre-programmed movements we've seen before, actual running with coordinated legs and real stride patterns. 
Running is fundamentally harder than walking because the robot loses ground contact and has to solve balance in mid air while controlling energy output. If they're comfortable showing this publicly, their motor control and AI training have leveled up significantly.
This matters because a humanoid that can run and navigate dynamic environments isn't confined to factory floors anymore. 
You're talking about real deployment potential in warehouses, construction sites and service work, places designed for human bodies. That's when the unit economics and scaling potential actually become viable.
Tesla's the only player positioned to win here. They own the vertical stack, proprietary AI, sensor data from millions of vehicles feeding back into training, their own chips, and manufacturing that actually scales. 
Boston Dynamics and Figure AI might have better algorithms on paper but they don't have a flywheel or the ability to produce thousands of units cost effectively. Tesla's already built the supply chain for complexity and mass production.
Most of the market still sees Optimus as 2030 science fair material but if they're casually demoing running robots now and can solve the cost problem, that's a multi hundred billion dollar business hiding in plain sight.
The real bet is whether Tesla can actually execute on production and cost which given their track record with EVs is more plausible than people think. 
- 
Milk Road AI

title: OpenAI just admitted it is no longer running unopp...
content:
OpenAI just admitted it is no longer running unopposed in frontier AI. 
Googleâ€™s Gemini 3 is good enough and growing fast enough, that Sam Altman reportedly told teams to halt side projects and go allâ€‘in on improving ChatGPT.
That is the same existential threat to the core product language Google used internally when it flagged ChatGPT as a risk to search in 2022.â€‹
This is already showing up in the numbers. In the two weeks since the Gemini launch, ChatGPTâ€™s unique daily active users on a 7â€‘day average are down about 6%, a real hit for a product at this scale. 
That pullback explains why management is willing to freeze things like ads and side experiments and force the company back into pure product defense mode.â€‹
For the AI trade, this is bullish competition and brutal margin pressure at the same time. 
Labs are now forced to spend more on compute, data and talent just to avoid losing share, which is great for the full AI stack from GPUs to power infrastructure, but less great for model only economics. 
The bigger picture, the disruptor that once triggered Googleâ€™s code red is now issuing its own over a Google product, which shows how quickly leadership can flip in this cycle and how valuable the real picks and shovels will be as the model layer starts to look more and more like a commodity.
OPENAI'S "CODE RED" ANNOUNCEMENT:
The irony of this announcement is that Google was the FIRST tech giant to issue a "code red."
On December 21st, 2022, exactly 3 WEEKS after ChatGPT was announced, Google issued their "code red."
Google was concerned about ChatGPT's threat to "the future of Google's search engine."
Today, OpenAI has issued their first "code red" as Google's Gemini 3 model has seen massive growth.
OpenAI is now pausing many of their "side projects" to focus on improving ChatGPT amid increased competition.
What does this all mean?
In our view, this is extremely bullish and yet another sign of the technological revolution we are in now.
The immense competition we are seeing in AI is the perfect example of why capitalism is the backbone of innovation.
More competition = more innovation = more value creation.
Asset owners will win. 
- 
The Kobeissi Letter
